list_definition.definition: a fine mist of small flying drops (of water etc) such as that given out by a waterfall

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The perfume came out of the bottle in a fine spray.

list_definition.definition: a device with many small holes, or other instrument, for producing a fine mist of liquid

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She used a spray to rinse her hair.
He bought a can of fly-spray.

list_definition.definition: to (cause liquid to) come out in a mist or in fine jets

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The water sprayed all over everyone.

list_definition.definition: to cover with a mist or with fine jets of liquid

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He sprayed the roses to kill pests.

list_ex_of_english: Significant seed-set was not observed in the control entries (male-sterile lines in absence of pollinators and insecticide sprays applied).
Municipal employees sprayed the house with steam, and 'screens' obstructing light and air in the house were burnt.
Successive sprays were separated by at least 14 d and a maximum of three sprays were applied in the growing season.
Several participants said that they do not agree with the claim that spraying by conventional farmers provides organic farmers with 'free protection'.
Plots sprayed with insecticides were sampled at monthly intervals to confirm that the plants were free of insect damage.
Suggested management strategies to minimize desiccation include spraying during the evening and using supplemental wetting prior to or following application.
The plants were sprayed until run-off (approximately 100 ml per plant) and then left to dry for 60 min before being placed in a cage.
Reduced feeding by caterpillars was termed a feeding restraint effect and the refusal to eat leaves sprayed with solution was termed an anti-feeding effect.
